instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 4v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
So this board turned up with dead short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> turned out to be <CAPACITOR>C7431</CAPACITOR> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> then gave a flickering voltage from 8.5v to 4.0v but now only puts out 4v
changed <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> have checked pins 27 and 28 get 20,2 ohms is the next move an SMC change?? or am i missing something

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 4v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Do NOT touch the SMC this is likely not the issue. What is the resistance between pins 17/18 of the ISL?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 4v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Remove F7140 and check voltage at L7130.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 4v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: i got 2.2 ohms on this, is this another sensing circuit?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 4v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: just removed f7140 and get 8.56v on L7130

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 4v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Please don't use comments we can't see them right away. If you get 8.56 at L7130, then you either have a blown fuse or a short on pin 2. What is your resistance to ground on pin 2 of F7140?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 4v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
If you get correct voltage at L7130 removing F7140, then your problem is on the system side of <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> rail.
Post resistance to ground on that side.

Check for short on any big coil (secondary supplies),
Will be better to post diode mode to ground on all, as in <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> too.
Switch to ohm mode only for less than 010 value.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 4v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
firstly thank you both so very much for your help!  

so on pin 2 of F7140 i get a diode reading of 0.14 V.



So i (with your help)have found the fault!!!!!!


when testing for a short i soldered my positive end to the fuse f7140 as this was fairly large. i must have affected the fuse because i just tested it and it gives me a reading of  3 ohms soldered in a plain piece of wire and get 8,56v and fan spin!!!!  just off to run up and down the stairs now!!

but question what reading in diode mode/resistance makes you start to wonder about a short circuit?

thanks again
john fursdon

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 4v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Was not really short, as you got 4V with F7140 in circuit.
But voltage in from of F7140 goes to correct level when fuse removed.
That denotes an issue after the fuse, on the system side (pin 2/F7140).
